data.title: MTNL shares hit 20% upper circuit on asset monetization plan, budget 2025 boost
data.description:
he MTNL stock has gained over 17 percent in the past three months.

Shares of Mahanagar Telephone Nigam Ltd. (MTNL) hit the 20 percent upper circuit of Rs 57.21 in morning trade on Wednesday, February 5, as optimism around its asset monetization plans for FY26 fueled a sharp rally. This surge followed a 7 percent gain in the previous session, breaking a two-day losing streak.

The rally was driven by comments from Arunish Chawla, Secretary of the Department of Disinvestment and Public Asset Management (DIPAM), during CNBC-TV18’s Budget 2025 Verdict discussion. Chawla reaffirmed the government’s commitment to helping MTNL and BSNL monetize their assets to unlock value, clear liabilities, and revitalize the sector.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

Follow our LIVE blog for all the latest market updates

MTNL, burdened with heavy debt, was classified as a Non-Performing Asset (NPA) by most state-owned lenders in October last year. Meanwhile, Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman, in her Union Budget 2025 speech, announced a new scheme aimed at providing broadband connectivity to select government schools and health centres.

As a result, the entire telecom pack rallied with BSE Telecom index up 1.4 percent at 2,806.

However, despite the renewed policy focus on the sector, the Indian government’s telecom revenue is expected to decline by over 33 percent to Rs 82,442.84 crore in FY26 from Rs 1,23,357.20 crore in the current fiscal, according to budget documents. This sharp drop comes despite upcoming payments from telecom operators for deferred spectrum and adjusted gross revenue (AGR) dues after the moratorium ends in September 2025.

Government earnings from the telecom sector primarily come from license fees and spectrum usage charges (SUC), both linked to telcos' AGR. Operators pay 8 percent of their AGR as license fees, while SUC, which was previously around 3-4 percent, has now fallen below 1 percent following the removal of the 3 percent floor and the waiver on SUC for spectrum acquired post-July 2022. Revenue from captive telecom networks comes through fixed license fees and a nominal one-time entry fee.

At around 10:20 am, shares of MTNL were trading at Rs 56.6 on the NSE, up 18.8 percent from the previous close. The MTNL stock has gained over 17 percent in the past three months.

data.title: Cummins India shares surge after parent projects double-digit revenue growth in India
data.description:
Cummins said it plans to invest more India, along other geographies, to ramp up capacity to meet the power generation demand.

Shares of Cummins India are higher in early trade on February 5 after parent Cummins Inc projected a double-digit revenue growth in India for 2024, riding on strong domestic demand for power generation.

The parent reported fourth quarter results that were above estimate, powered by a rise in power demand from data centers of big tech majors, helping post strong sales growth. However, Cummins Inc said it sees the annual sales falling, as North American heavy-duty truck segment still is sluggish.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

"In India, we project total revenue, including joint venture to increase 10% in 2024, primarily driven by stronger power generation demand," said Cummins Inc chairman and CEO, Jennifer Rumsey.

Cummins said it plans to invest more India, along other geographies, to ramp up capacity to meet the power generation demand. " In order to further raise our capacity to meet rising power generation demand, we also intend to invest $200 million across our U.S., England and India manufacturing sites," said the CEO.

"we're currently in the midst of a $200 million investment across our plants in Seymour and Minnesota, U.K., and India to ramp up capacity to meet what is a growing demand for power generation products. And so you're seeing in that guide an expectation that we have been able to take up capacity," Cummins Inc added.

For its India heavy and medium truck business, Cummins has projected a wide range of demand for 2025, from down 5% to up 5%.

The race for artificial intelligence among big tech giants has been a key driver for power demand for Cummins, leading to a revenue growth projection of 5-15% for the company in the global power generation market.

India's per capita electricity consumption has surged to 1,395 kWh in 2023-24, marking a 45.8% rise compared to 2013-14. India’s total installed power generation capacity has surged to 457 GW as of November 2024, according to government data.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

Shares of Cummins India are higher by over 2% on February 5, but are down nearly 10% so far this year. Over the last one year, Cummins India shares are higher by 24%. The company has a market capitalization of over Rs 81,000 crore.

data.title: Ajax Engineering sets price band of Rs 599-629 a share for IPO
data.description:
ICICI Securities, Citigroup Global Markets India, JM Financial, Nuvama Wealth Management, and SBI Capital Markets are the book-running lead managers for the IPO.

Ajax Engineering Ltd has set a price band of Rs 599-629 per share for its initial public offering (IPO), which opens on February 10. Anchor bidding will commence on February 7, and the issue will close on February 12.

The basis of allotment is scheduled for February 13, with refunds and credit of equity shares to demat accounts on February 14. The company's shares are set to list on exchanges on February 17.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

This IPO is a pure offer for sale of up to 2.02 crore shares by promoters and existing shareholders. At the upper price band, the total issue size will be approximately Rs 1,270 crore.

Ajax Engineering, a leading concrete equipment manufacturer with four assembly and manufacturing facilities in Karnataka, dominates the self-loading concrete mixers segment with a 77 percent market share. It competes with listed players such as Action Construction Equipment, BEML, and Escorts Kubota.

The company has demonstrated strong financial performance, with profit surging 65.7 percent year-on-year to Rs 225.1 crore in FY24, while revenue rose 51.3 percent to Rs 1,741.4 crore. In the six-month period ending September 2024, profit increased by 21.8 percent to Rs 101 crore, and revenue grew 12.4 percent to Rs 770 crore compared to the same period last year.

ICICI Securities, Citigroup Global Markets India, JM Financial, Nuvama Wealth Management, and SBI Capital Markets are the book-running lead managers for the IPO.

data.title: Brokers welcome algo-norms, but will wait for clarity before investing big
data.description:
Traders can hope to see two kinds of services mainly being offered through brokerages.

Brokers have been preparing themselves for the rollout of SEBI's new algorithmic-trading (algo trading) norms, which will support retail investors who want to trade using algos. But before taking the final plunge and investing big in what could be a significant opportunity, they are waiting for clarity to emerge on some aspects.

On February 4, the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) issued the circular detailing a framework to ensure safer participation of retail investors in algo trading through brokers. It came nearly a month earlier than industry participants had expected and were preparing for.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

According to the circular, the implementation standards will be formulated by April 1, 2025, and the provisions of the circular will come into effect from August 1, 2025.

Also read: MC exclusive: Illegal algorithm providers could get around SEBI's proposed norms; the trick lies in a set threshold

Brokerages Moneycontrol spoke to said that they were expecting  the new norms to be announced in March and had been consulting compliance and technology experts to ready products for this.

Industry players said that this could be a big boost for brokerages who have been reeling from recent regulatory orders issued on index-derivatives trading and ending the paybacks brokerages were receiving from exchanges for generating volumes. Yet some brokerages said that will invest gradually since they are still unsure about a few directives and about how trading volumes will be after after the index-derivatives norms trading fully play out; the deadline for two of the last directives was February 1 this year.

Why now?
In the circular, SEBI noted the increasing demand from retail investors for algo trading, which had made review and refinement of the existing regulations around algo trading necessary.

Algo trading has been regulated since 2012. But earlier, this service was restricted to institutional investors. Later, following the pandemic-led boom, the industry saw a growing demand for this service from retail traders.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

This even led to the setting up of unregistered algo marketplaces, from where retail investors could buy strategies and link it to their brokerage platforms. These arrangements had come under SEBI's scrutiny, with the regulator being concerned about the past-performance metrics advertised by such platforms to sell strategies. This practice was in violation of the regulator's September 2022 directive, which restrained stock brokers from being associated with any platform that provides references to past performance.

In October 2024, the regulator even issued notices to over 115 stock brokers for their continued association with the algo platform Tradetron.

According to market insiders, since then the regulator has been in conversation with brokerages and algo providers to understand how best to meet this demand in the market, while protecting retail investors and market integrity. They said that discussions with SEBI started in October-September 2023.

In December, a consultation paper came after such discussions, and in February, the final circular was issued.

What is coming

Meanwhile brokerages have been working in the background, getting services and products ready to launch.

Rajesh Sriwastava, founder of Quant Lab and a trader with over 20 years of experience, is now helping brokerages set up the technology needed to cater to retail traders' algo needs. This includes what hardware capacities they need to have and what the process of getting clearance for algos from exchanges is.

He is now advising three brokerages, including one run by a bank and another one listed, and is in conversation with four other brokerages.

According to Srivastawa, brokerages working in the background have been working to offer mainly two kinds of services/products. One, to cater to  investors who want a complex strategy coded and two, an easy, no-code way to create their own strategy.

In the first, investors will consult the brokerage's employees to create and code a strategy they have an outline of. In the second, investor can choose from drop-down lists to enter parameters for a strategy, which will be pre-coded. For both, once the strategy is ready, the brokerage will get it cleared through the exchanges before making it available for use for the investor.

Need more clarity

A senior executive at a leading brokerage welcomed the new norms, since it will make it make it easier for retail traders to automate their strategies. Another brokerage head said that several of them have the capacity ready to offer algos, but are waiting for more clarity on how to get clearances for algos and several other operational details.

Brokerages said that there needs to be clarity on the threshold that will determine algo trades from regular trades. That is, according to the circular, orders that are fired at a particular speed will be considered algo trades but the speed (or number of order per second) is yet to be defined. According to a senior executive, this will be released after the regulator's discussions with the industry standard forum (ISF).

Brokerages are also seek more clarity on the rules around white-box algos (where the logic is open to all) and black-box algos (where the logic is hidden).

Besides these concerns, the brokerages are also waiting to see how far trading volumes will drop after the complete implementation of the index-derivatives norms. Depending on how far the volumes drop, brokerages might decide how much to invest in providing algo solutions. A brokerage head said that if the volumes drop too far, they may see if there is an opportunity to offer strategies for the cash segment, instead of the derivatives segment where the focus has been so far.

According to Sriwastava, there is a fundamental shift in the way brokerages are now approaching their clients. "They (brokerages) never had a trader mindset, they have it now. Also, they do not want their clients to go out of their ecosystem, so they are trying to provide different services".

The latter is in reference to algo platforms. According to him, brokerages are taking the most popular features of these marketplaces and now incorporating them into their own platforms.

Last year, ITC had decided to demerge its Hotel business into a separate listed entity to unlock value for shareholders. It had fixed the demerger ratio at 1:10, which meant that shareholders holding 10 shares of ITC, as of January 6, 2025, would receive one share of ITC Hotels post the demerger.

Further, under the scheme of demerger, ITC Hotels issued equity shares directly to the shareholders of ITC in a manner that about 60 per cent stake is held directly by ITC shareholders proportionate to their shareholding in ITC and the remaining about 40 percent stake to continue with ITC.

data.title: Sensex, Nifty flat as RBI policy meet kicks off; mid-, small-caps gain over 1%
data.description:
India’s equity benchmarks opened flat on February 5 as the Reserve Bank of India kicks off its three-day monetary policy meeting. Investors are on edge, anticipating a widely expected rate cut aimed at reviving growth. With global trade uncertainties casting a shadow, all eyes are on the RBI’s decision due February 7, where a 25-basis-point cut remains the market’s base case.

"Even if there's no immediate rate cut, the RBI is likely to signal a softer stance," said Sunil Subramanian, Market Veteran, in a conversation with Moneycontrol. "Inflation has moderated, and oil prices could stabilise with Trump reviving old oil wells. These factors create room for a rate cut, though it may come in the next quarter. If the RBI surprises with a cut now, rate-sensitive stocks could rally," he added.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

At 9.28 AM, the Sensex was down 5 points or 0.01 percent at 78,578, and the Nifty was up 31 points or 0.1 percent at 23,770. About 2,135 shares advanced, 672 shares declined, and 110 shares were unchanged.

Meanwhile, after a long lull, foreign institutional investors (FIIs) returned as net buyers on February 4, purchasing Indian equities worth Rs 809 crore. This came on the back of a nearly 2 percent surge in benchmark indices after the U.S. paused planned tariffs on Canada and Mexico. However, FIIs remain net sellers for February, having offloaded Rs 4,476 crore worth of Indian shares so far.

Follow our live blog for all the market action

New Leadership, New Approach

Subramanian highlighted that new RBI Governor Sanjay Malhotra appears more aligned with the government's economic agenda. "Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman also recently met with the RBI, suggesting greater coordination between fiscal and monetary policies," he said recalling.

Trump's Tariff Tango

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

Globally, markets are closely tracking U.S. President Donald Trump’s shifting stance on tariffs. On February 1, he imposed 25 percent tariffs on Canada and Mexico, along with a 10 percent levy on Chinese goods, citing illegal immigration and the drug trade. Just two days later, he softened his approach, granting a 30-day reprieve for Canada and Mexico in exchange for stronger border security commitments. Tariffs on China, however, remain firmly in place.

"It seems like he's using tariffs as a bargaining tool to gain concessions. The market senses that he may not actually implement them," Subramaniam said. "While a full-fledged trade war seems unlikely, Trump is using this as leverage. If tariffs are enforced, U.S. inflation will rise, which could deter the Fed from cutting rates—something Trump actually wants to keep the U.S. competitive. It's a complex situation, but Trump, being a businessman, likely sees this as a strategic move to secure a better deal for the U.S. Markets are sensing a give-and-take approach rather than unilateral action," he explained.

Domestic Spotlight: Delhi Elections

Back home, the political stage is heating up as Delhi gears up for its high-stakes assembly elections. With 699 candidates contesting across 70 seats, the battle is shaping up to be a fierce one. Arvind Kejriwal's Aam Aadmi Party is eyeing a third consecutive term, facing a determined challenge from the BJP. In 2020, AAP dominated with 62 seats, following a landslide 67-seat victory in 2015.

Technical Take

Anand James, Chief Market Strategist at Geojit Financial Services said, "While we are content to have reached the target range that has been in play for over a week, the potential for even larger upside remains a fair possibility." He said that since Nifty closed above the upper Bollinger Band and is near the 50 SMA for the first time since January, a pullback seems likely before a breakout above 23,789. "If dips thereof are contained above 23,550, expect spikes to, but not exceeding 24,020 or 24,226," James added.

Global Markets

On Wall Street, major U.S. indexes closed higher on February 4, supported by energy stocks and optimism surrounding Trump's softened tariff stance.

Asia-Pacific markets were mixed today after Wall Street rose overnight, shrugging off Trump tariffs and China's retaliatory measures. China's CSI 300 Index initially opened higher post-Lunar New Year but reversed to drop 0.6 percent. Meanwhile, the country's Caixin Services PMI fell to 51.0 in January from 52.2 in December, signalling a slowdown in services activity.

data.title: Gold rises to all-time high on Sino-US tariff war
data.description:
Spot gold was up 0.2% at $2,848.69 per ounce, as of 0253 GMT, after hitting a record high of $2,853.97 earlier in the session.

Gold prices hit a record high on Wednesday, bolstered by fears of a new trade war between the United States and China after Beijing slapped tariffs on U.S. imports in a response to new U.S. duties on Chinese goods.

Spot gold was up 0.2% at $2,848.69 per ounce, as of 0253 GMT, after hitting a record high of $2,853.97 earlier in the session. US gold futures gained 0.2% to $2,879.70.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

US President Donald Trump said on Tuesday he is in no hurry to speak to Chinese President Xi Jinping to try to defuse the trade tensions between the world’s two largest economies.

China imposed targeted tariffs on U.S. imports on Tuesday and put several companies, including Google, on notice for possible sanctions, in a measured response to Trump’s tariffs.

"The next major inflection point for gold is probably the $3,000 figure… China may be more encouraged to keep buying gold for reserves if the trade war escalates," said Ilya Spivak, head of global macro at Tastylive.

Meanwhile, the Trump administration’s plans for trade tariffs come with inflation risks, three Federal Reserve officials warned on Monday, with one arguing that uncertainty over the price outlook calls for slower interest rate cuts than otherwise.

While gold is considered an inflation hedge, higher interest rates could dampen its appeal among investors.

Key economic data on investors’ radar this week includes the ADP employment report due at 1315 GMT and the payrolls report on Friday, which could shed more light on the health of the U.S. economy.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

"Gold demand ought to be partially supportive for other precious metals but their sensitivity to risk appetite has seen them underperform," said Spivak.

Spot silver rose 0.2% to $32.15 per ounce, platinum edged 0.3% higher to $966.95, and palladium fell 0.9% to $981.75.

data.title: Tata Power shares gain 3% following strong Q3 earnings, brokerages mixed on outlook
data.description:
Tata Power Company's stock price has slipped 15 percent over the previous three months.

Shares of Tata Power Company rose 3 percent to Rs 373 on February 5 after the company reported a 10 percent year-on-year rise in consolidated net profit to Rs 1,188 crore for the third quarter of FY24-25, surpassing expectations. The earnings boost was attributed to better realization across its core businesses—generation, transmission, distribution, and renewables.

Revenue grew 3 percent to Rs 15,793 crore, while EBITDA rose 7 percent to Rs 3,481 crore, driven by operational efficiencies and business synergies. CEO and MD Praveer Sinha highlighted the company’s consistent profit growth over 21 quarters, underscoring contributions from all segments.

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

Follow our LIVE blog for all the latest market updates

Brokerages, however, remained divided on the stock. Nuvama maintained a "Reduce" rating with a target price of Rs 343, noting that growth was driven by one-off income from the Mundra plant. While the company is ramping up solar module and cell manufacturing, Nuvama believes risks outweigh rewards at the current valuation of 2.9 times FY26 estimated price-to-book value.

Morgan Stanley remained bullish with an "Overweight" call and a target of Rs 583 per share, despite weaker-than-expected numbers across most business segments except for Mumbai and Odisha discoms. The firm highlighted a planned capex spend of Rs 10,000 crore in Q4 and guided for 600 MW of renewable energy commissioning in the same period.

Also read: Asia shares edge higher, dollar backtracks amid hopes US tariffs won't be painful

CLSA, however, maintained an "Underperform" rating with a target price of Rs 351, citing weak Q3 results led by subsidiary Tata Projects, which pulled PAT down by 6 percent year-on-year. Profitability in the company’s renewable independent power producer (IPP) business was hit by lower solar and wind utilization rates and rising interest costs. Additionally, coal profit per tonne fell 17 percent year-on-year due to a decline in seaborne coal prices. The only bright spot was the renewable energy EPC business, which benefited from India’s solar module import ban.

Tata Power’s renewable push continued with Tata Power Renewable Energy Ltd (TPREL) commissioning a 126 MWp floating solar project in Omkareshwar and a 431 MW DC solar plant in Neemuch, Madhya Pradesh—the latter being India’s first to integrate single-axis trackers with bi-facial modules. The company also hit a milestone of 16 lakh smart meter installations across its discoms in Mumbai, Delhi, and Odisha.

data.title: Blue Dart shares rise 2% as Goldman Sachs maintains 'buy', sees 22% upside
data.description:
Blue Dart Express's share price has tanked over 18 percent in the last three months.

Shares of Blue Dart Express rallied over 2 percent to Rs 6,543 in morning trade on February 5, snapping its three-day losing streak on the bourses after Goldman Sachs maintained a "Buy" rating on the stock and raised the target price.

With a buy call, the international brokerage assigned a price target of Rs 7,720, implying an upside potential of 22 percent from the last closing price of Rs 6,383 on the National Stock Exchange (NSE).

Story continues below Advertisement
Remove Ad

Follow our LIVE blog for all the latest market updates

The brokerage maintained its rating even as the company's second quarter revenue and EBITDA missed estimates by 2 percent and 6 percent, respectively. Parcel volume grew 7 percent year-on-year, while tonnage increased 12 percent, with surface transport outpacing air freight. However, freight margins deteriorated by 10 basis points quarter-on-quarter, contrary to the 80 basis points expansion Goldman had expected. The brokerage finds Blue Dart's valuation attractive at 27 times its estimated FY27 earnings.

Blue Dart reported a strong sequential performance in Q3 FY25, with consolidated net profit rising 28.9 percent to Rs 81.01 crore from Rs 62.84 crore in the previous quarter. Total income grew 4.6 percent to Rs 1,523.65 crore, while profit before tax (PBT) surged 28.7 percent to Rs 109.26 crore.

However, on a year-on-year basis, net profit declined 8.9 percent, even as total income rose 9.3 percent. PBT saw a modest increase of 1.6 percent compared to the same period last year.

Managing Director Balfour Manuel highlighted the company’s resilience and adaptability, attributing its performance to a well-balanced mix of B2B and B2C solutions. He noted that disciplined execution and operational efficiency have enabled Blue Dart to navigate market challenges while maintaining consistent growth and long-term value.

Looking ahead, Manuel emphasized the company’s commitment to building a future-ready logistics ecosystem, with a focus on sustainability, scalability, and service excellence. Strategic investments in efficiency and environmental responsibility, he said, will ensure seamless and reliable logistics solutions for stakeholders.
